---
layout: post
title: "Explainable AI: Reasoning with Natural Language"
---


## Motivation and Problem Statement


**What is explainable AI and Why do we need it?**

Today, Artificial Intelligence (AI) has become a familiar word to most people, and it has been employed in a variety of fields to help tackle many challenging problems. These applications, however, often provide us a solution without revealing the logic and reasoning behind it. In other words, it functions as a blackbox.

![fig1](data:image/jpeg;base64,)


Explainable AI, are AI models which can not only provide an answer to a question but also give reasonable explanations for how they arrive at a conclusion or a decision. With knowledge and understanding of the mechanism and behavior of AI models, we can build better tools with greater efficiency, transparency, and reliability.


There is a growing need for explainable AI in numerous industries, such as business, where AI is used to help professionals make prudent investment and commercial decisions, or in the healthcare industry, where machines assist doctors and practitioners in making accurate medical diagnoses and designing best treatment plans.


 **What is controlled natural language(CNL) and Why do we use it?**

It is a language understandable by humans and machines both. Controlled Natural Languages (CNL) are languages that are based on natural language but apply restrictions on vocabulary, grammar, and/or semantics. CNLs are unambiguous and simple as opposed to their base languages. They preserve the expressiveness and coherence of natural languages.

  
Example of some CNL:

-   ASD-STE100 Simplified Technical English
-   Attempto Controlled English
-   Regelspraak
-   Semantics of Business Vocabulary and Business Rules (SBVR)
-   Seaspeak

Some CNLs are designed to improve communication among humans, especially for non-native speakers. In other cases, the restrictions on the language makes it easier for computers to analyze such texts to improve computer-aided, semi-automatic, or automatic translations into other languages. A third group of CNL has the goal to enable reliable automated reasoning and formal knowledge representation from seemingly natural texts. In this project we are concerned about this third group of CNLs.
To put it more simply, the question that we ask is: Can we reason with Controlled Natural Language? If so, to what extent?

  

In this project, we want to investigate the possibility to reason with a ‘controlled’ natural language, our aim is to build a reasoning tool that can perform logical reasoning tasks phrased in a controlled natural language, and also provide explanations for conclusions it derives.

~~(I still think we should introduce a bit about the semantic tableau method in the intro part, before it’s sudden appearance in research questions)~~

---
## Research Questions

In this project, we attempt to address the following research questions:

-   Which subset of natural language can be used to reason in the semantic natural tableau method?
-   How should the semantic tableau method be adapted to directly reason with natural language?  
-   To what extent must the natural language structure be specified and con-strained for the semantic tableau method in order to reason with it?    
-   Is it possible for the semantic tableau method to handle defeasible information?
    

## Approaches

To reason with a Controlled Natural Language the first thing we need to do is define a controlled natural language ourselves. For that we defined a very simple CNL based on English which follows some very simple rules.

-   [We need to define these rules in the simplest of terms]
-   Rule 1   
-   Rule 2
-   Rule 3
-   Rule 4

Based on these rules, our controlled natural language is set. Now to reason with this CNL we have chosen the Semantic Tableaux method. Let us expand on what this method means for a bit.

Semantic tableaux is based on the idea of proof by contradiction. It is a refutation-based system. Semantic tableaux is a form of backward proof because we start from the conclusion and decompose it and the premises into smaller and smaller parts until we reach a contradiction.

We can represent this as a tree representing all the ways the conjunction of the formulas at the root can be true. We expand the formulas based on the structure of the compound formulas. This expansion forms a tree. If all branches in the tableau lead to a contradiction, then there is no way the conjunction of the formulas at the root can be true. A path of the tree represents the conjunction of the formulas along the path. Semantic tableaux was invented by E.W. Beth and J. Hintikka (1965).

We can picture this better with the following simple sketch:

![](https://lh5.googleusercontent.com/7xc9afeBx92giMcaIpeyiEDhqtKhPfxN2WygoOsfMpjiUvYBwk9Y2Sx36-yLwKu7igfjC1pAI0QlS9Y4RE2_iKsqegasuA81uut-HTgsYaalWP23iXd79tjTCcrUNUb5WZopERH3)

**Example 2** A syllogism (Argument with premises and conclusion)

Premises: All men are afraid of Dracula. | ∀x(Mx → Dx)
Aristotle is a man. | Ma
Conclusion: Aristotle is afraid of Dracula. | Da

![](https://lh4.googleusercontent.com/lrzYvqLJnydFdJZD_q8GEUbB7H6_uoLD9vxSOC12Ns_adin0Gh724G9YbTq5uY81AXyyPNlGmWjxWR2kIhi2y3pMDQRcDjTQYMf29DXX-5osr7jN4C-WkjMOc-Wac1B8wlglBBYj)

## Future Goals

As our implementation at the current stage is limited, future studies can be done on how to implement the semantic tableau method on controlled language reasoning more effectively and successfully. For example, how to devise this semantic tableau reasoning tool so that it can provide explainable arguments and conclusions with high accuracy and fast speed.

Another direction would be to explore feasible ways to apply the tableau method on other controlled languages as well as other logics, and by adopting the reasoning tool to different cases, we can empower the tool, making it more flexible and useful.

Lastly, we can investigate possible approaches to create a test dataset of certain standards. This dataset consists of one or several controlled natural languages along with their corresponding defeasible information specified, and with such a dataset, we can better measure and assess the performance of the reasoning tool.
